This may be a stupid question, but would the increase in tariffs be an incentive for American companies to move out of China and back to the US? Like Nike, or Wal-Mart, companies like that?

 
 It isn't a stupid question. For discussion purposes I'll use the furniture industry, one of the primary lobby groups pushing the tariff. A 27% tariff would make the cost of Chinese produced furniture landed in the US approximately equal to US production costs. Before addressing the feasibility of relocating furniture production to the US, keep in mind all furniture imported into the US has now gone up 27% to the consumer, who is also experiencing reduced buying power due to stagnant wages, etc.
 
 Most US (and other foreign companies) manufacturing in China do so on a joint venture basis, 50/50, with the Chinese entity retaining control and all assets should the venture be terminated. To assume a company is servicing only the US (generally not the actuality) and for that company to relocate to another country, and it wouldn't be the US due to our very high labor cost of goods sold and operating costs, they would be required to abandon that capital and furnish new capital for facilities in Vietnam, India, Malaysia or another low production cost country. 
 
 The move to tariffs is a US political gambit prompted by party contributors (US manufacturers). The bulk of furniture in the US is purchased from mass merchandisers such as Wal-Mart and those high volume, low quality furniture chains and the furniture rental firms who use full-page ads to offer low prices and easy credit. They'll buy from whomever offers the lowest cost of goods. So we're left with the US consumer paying 27% more for furniture and seeking lower costs. If furniture production (or any other product) is then moved to say Malaysia do we then slap the tariffs on them? And every other country? 
 
 Then China and other countries begin placing tariffs on US goods, a trade war, further diminishing our exports which will put our already massive trade imbalance and negative balance of payments in even more trouble. The simplistic explanation of the entire situation is that our high standard of living has made us uncompetitive in global markets. Tariffs will not remedy that circumstance, all they'll do is temporarily crutch inefficient US manufacturing and allow US consumers (briefly) to support overpaid workers in US facilities.
